changestmt.respstmt: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Assistant Editor: Michael Fox Managing Editor: Joseph Fletcher Assistant Project Manager: Grant Glass Project Coordinator, University of Rochester: Eric Loy Consultants on Special Projects: Ashley Reed, Nikolaus Wasmoen, Laura Whitebell Bibliographer: Mark Crosby Project Assistants: Katherine Calvin, Erin Francisco, Ani Govjian, Rachael Isom, Joey Kingsley, Mary Learner, Rob Rich, Anneke Schwob, Oishani Sengupta, Elizabeth Shand, Matthew Skwiat, Jewell Thomas, Marcie Woehl, Meaghan Green, Kendall DeBoer Helen Davies

Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Assistant Editor: Michael Fox Managing Editor: Joseph Fletcher Assistant Project Manager: Grant Glass Project Coordinator, University of Rochester: Eric Loy Consultants on Special Projects: Ashley Reed, Nikolaus Wasmoen, Laura Whitebell Bibliographer: Mark Crosby Project Assistants: Katherine Calvin, Erin Francisco, Ani Govjian, Alison Harper, Rachael Isom, Joey Kingsley, Mary Learner, Rob Rich, Anneke Schwob, Oishani Sengupta, Elizabeth Shand, Matthew Skwiat, Jewell Thomas, Emily Tronson, Lisa Vandenbossche, Alex Zawacki

Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Technical Editor: William Shaw Project Manager: Ashley Reed Project Coordinator, University of Rochester: Rachel Lee Project Assistants: Esther Arnold, Kate Attkisson, Laura Bell, Lauren Cameron, Katherine Carlson, Cassandra Etter-Wenzel, Andrea Everett, Joseph Fletcher Ali McGhee, Jennifer Park, Adair Rispoli, Sarah Shaw, Hardeep Sidhu, Sarah Tolf, Nikolaus Wasmoen, Bihan Zhang

objinfo.objsize: ranging between 7 x 20 cm. (approx. fragment size) and 15 x 20 cm. (approx. leaf size)

provenance.name: City of Westminster Archives Centre
provenance.note: Objects 1-6 and 8-29 as numbered here: Thomas Butts; from the Butts collection; acquired from Butt’s grandson, Captain Butts between 1903 and 1906 by the late W. Graham Robertson; bequeathed by Robertson to his executor, Kerrison Preston about 1948; presented by Preston with his Blake collection to the City of Westminster Reference Library in 1967.

provenance.name: Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery
provenance.note: Object 8 as numbered here: Thomas Butts; from the Butts collection; acquired by Ruthven Todd no later than 1942; sold in April 1998 in a catalogue of Marvin Sadik Fine Arts of Scarborough, Maine, April 1998 catalogue no. 1, 8th unnumbered item, illustrated in color (not priced); acquired by John Windle and bequeathed by him to the Huntington Library in May 1998 with funds provided by Robert Essick.

provenance.name: Yale University Library
provenance.note: Objects 30-44 as numbered here: John Linnell; from the Linnell collection; sold at Christie's, Dec. 2, 1938 to the dealer W.H. Robinson on behalf on Otis T. Bradley (in Lot 62 £78 15s); presented to Yale University Library by Mr. Otis T. Bradley in 1941 or 1942.

repository.institution: Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery

repository.department: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

desc.objtitle:
22 January 1805 Receipt, Thomas Butts, 22 January 1805,
Object 1 (Bentley Receipt 3)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 8.0 x 20.0 cm.

objnote.p: On the left of the receipt there is a revenue stamp embossed depicting a shield bearing the Union Flag and the motto “Dieu et Mon Droit”. Above the shield is a coronet and on the left and right sides are sprigs of long, narrow leaves.Below the shield is the phrase “FOR RECEIPTS/FOUR PENCE”.
On the top right corner, the number "1" is inscribed in pencil in an unknown hand.

desc.objtitle:
7 September 1805 Receipt, Thomas Butts, 7 September 1805,
Object 2 (Bentley Receipt 5)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 7.5 x 19 cm.

objnote.p: To the left of the text is an embossed revenue stamp depicting a shield bearing the union flag and surrounded by the motto “DIEU ET MON DROIT”. Above the shield is a coronet and on the left and right sides are sprigs of long, narrow leaves. Below the shield is the phrase “TWO PENCE / FOR RECEIPT”.
On the top right corner, the number "2" is inscribed in pencil in an unknown hand.

desc.objtitle:
May-December 1805, page 1 Accounts between Blake and Thomas Butts, May-December 1805,
Object 3 (Bentley Receipt 6.1)

physdesc.objsize: On a sheet of paper 15.6 x 18.9 cm.

objnote.p: This receipt is written on both sides of a full sheet of paper and continued on a slip of paper attached by a wafer to the sheet. This object is the recto.

lg.l: 1 Famine 2 War 3 Moses Striking the Rock
7 Christ Baptizing 8 Samson breakgbreaking bonds Keynes (Letters, 113) reads "breakg" as "breaking". Bentley (Blake Records, 764) reads "breakg" as "breakg".
9 Samson subdudsubdued 10 Noah & Rainbow Keynes (Letters, 113) reads "subdud" as "subdu'd".
11 Wise & foolish Virgins 12 Hell beneath is
1 Good & Evil Angel 2 House of Death
3 God CreatingJudging Adam 4 Lamech __ 4.4.0 Bentley (*Blake Records*, 764) reads the deletion as"Creating" and the addition as "Judging".Keynes (*Letters*, 113) reads "Judging".
3 God Creating Adam 4 Christ appearing __ 4.4.0 Bentley (*Blake Records*, 764) and Keynes (*Letters*, 113) read the addition as "appearing".

desc.objtitle:
May-December 1805, page 1 Accounts between Blake and Thomas Butts, May-December 1805,
Object 4 (Bentley Receipt 6.2)

physdesc.objsize: On a sheet of paper 15.6 x 18.9 cm.

objnote.p: This receipt is written on both sides of a full sheet of paper and continued on a slip of paper attached by a wafer to the sheet. This object is the verso .

lg.l: from Felpham___}14,,14 previous to my going Lines 3-4 are enclosed by an incomplete parenthesis on the right.
& Songs of Experience —By Coals to 5: Octo.rOctober
3 Hayleys Ballads + Brother — ,, 7. 61805 _________ }12,,19 — Lines 6-8 are enclosed by an incomplete parenthesis on the right.
On Account of teaching your Son
to commence on this Day Bentley (*Blake Records*, 766) reads "commence" as "Commence". Lines 13-16 are enclosed by an incomplete parenthesis on the right.

desc.objtitle:
March 3 1806 Receipt, Thomas Butts, March 3 1806,
Object 5 (Bentley Receipt 6.3)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 17.8 x 20 cm.

objnote.p: This receipt is written on both sides of a full sheet of paper and continued on a slip of paper attached by a wafer to the sheet. This object is the slip of paper.

On the left of the receipt there is a revenue stamp embossed depicting a shield bearing the Union Flag and the motto “Dieu et Mon Droit”. Above the shield is a coronet and on the left and right sides are sprigs of long, narrow leaves.Below the shield is the phrase “FOR RECEIPTS/FOUR PENCE”.
On the top right corner, the number "3" is inscribed in pencil in an unknown hand.

lg.l: RecievdReceived of Mr Butts. March 3. 1806 the Sum of Keynes (Lettersp. 114) reads "Recievd" as "Receiv'd".
Sixteen Pounds Seven & Four pence Balance to this

Day as Per Annexed Account Bentley (*Blake Records*, 766) and Keynes (*Letters*, 114) read "Day" as "day" and "Per" as "per".Bentley (*Blake Records*, 766) and Keynes (*Letters*, 114) read the addition as "Annexed".

desc.objtitle:
30 June 1806 Receipt, Thomas Butts, 30 June 1806,
Object 6 (Bentley Receipt 7)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 7.5 x 18.5 cm.

objnote.p: To the left of the text is an embossed revenue stamp depicting a coronet and sprigs of long, narrow leaves on its left and right. The word “RECEIPT” appears at the top and the words “EIGHT PENCE” at the bottom.
On the top right corner, the number "4" is inscribed in pencil in an unknown hand.

lg.l: one Pounds ten Shillings on account forKeynes(Letters, 114) and Bentley (Blake Records, 766) read "Pounds" as "pounds".
WillmWilliamBlakeThe letters "ll" are written in pencil and retraced in ink.

desc.objtitle:
9 September 1806 Receipt to Thomas Butts, 9 September 1806,
Object 7 (Bentley Receipt 8)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 7.7 x 18.6 cm.

objnote.p: To the left of the text is an embossed revenue stamp depicting a shield bearing the union flag and surrounded by the motto “DIEU ET MON DROIT”. Above the shield is a coronet and on the left and right sides are sprigs of long, narrow leaves. Below the shield is the phrase “TWO PENCE / FOR RECEIPTS”.

lg.l: Received of Mr. Butts six Keynes (Lettersp. 123) reads "Received" as "Receiv'd".

desc.objtitle:
15 October 1806 Receipt, Thomas Butts, 15 October 1806,
Object 8 (Bentley Receipt 9)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 7.7 x 18.6 cm.

objnote.p: To the left of the text is an embossed revenue stamp depicting a shield bearing the union flag and surrounded by the motto “DIEU ET MON DROIT”. Above the shield is a coronet and on the left and right sides are sprigs of long, narrow leaves. Below the shield is the phrase “TWO PENCE / FOR RECEIPTS”.
On the top right corner, the number "5" is inscribed in pencil in an unknown hand.

desc.objtitle:
3 March 1807 Receipt, Thomas Butts, 3 March 1807,
Object 9 (Bentley Receipt 11)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 7.4 x 18.8 cm.

objnote.p: To the left of the text is an embossed revenue stamp depicting a coronet and sprigs of long, narrow leaves on its left and right. The word “RECEIPT” appears at the top and the words “EIGHT PENCE” at the bottom.
On the top right corner, the number "6" is inscribed in pencil in an unknown hand.
Blake writes the latter half of the receipt (lines 4-7) in pencil. Bentley (*Blake Records*, page 767) notes that the figures in pencil itemize the work for which the money was due.

lg.l: Recievd RecievedMarch 3. 1807 of Mr Butts the Sum of Bentley (*Blake Records*,766) and Keynes (*Letters*, 123) read "Recieved".
Twenty Eight Pounds Six Shillings on Account

l.note: Bentley (*Blake Records*, page 767) and Keynes (*Letters*, page 124) read “Drawings in,” but the two words, written in pencil, are obscured in the manuscript.
Bentley (*Blake Records*, page 767) and Keynes (*Letters*, page 124) read the first price as “28.6,” but the number is unclear in the manuscript.
Keynes (*Letters*, page 124) read “25.4.6,” but the number is obscured in the manuscript.
Bentley (*Blake Records*, page 767) and Keynes (*Letters*, page 124) read “3.1.6,” but the number is obscured in the manuscript.

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 7.8 x 18.7 cm.

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 8.5 x 21.0 cm.

objnote.p: On the left of the receipt there is a revenue stamp embossed depicting a shield bearing the Union Flag and the motto “Dieu et Mon Droit”. Above the shield is a coronet and on the left and right sides are sprigs of long, narrow leaves.Below the shield is the phrase “FOR RECEIPTS/FOUR PENCE”.

desc.objtitle:
6 October 1807 Receipt, Thomas Butts, 6 October 1807,
Object 12 (Bentley Receipt 14)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 8.4 x 21.0 cm.

objnote.p: On the left of the receipt there is a revenue stamp embossed depicting a shield bearing the Union Flag and the motto “Dieu et Mon Droit”. Above the shield is a coronet and on the left and right sides are sprigs of long, narrow leaves.Around the shield is written “FOR RECEIPTS” and below “FOUR PENCE”.
On the top right corner, the number "9" is inscribed in pencil in an unknown hand.

desc.objtitle:
14 January 1808 Receipt, Thomas Butts, 14 January 1808,
Object 13 (Bentley Receipt 15)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 7.7 x 19.5 cm.

objnote.p: To the left of the text is an embossed revenue stamp depicting a shield bearing the union flag and surrounded by the motto “DIEU ET MON DROIT”. Above the shield is a coronet and on the left and right sides are sprigs of long, narrow leaves. Below the shield is the phrase “TWO PENCE / FOR RECEIPTS”.
On the top right corner, the number "10" is inscribed in pencil in an unknown hand.
The signature on the receipt is not in Blake's hand. Keynes (Letters, 131) and Bentley (Blake Records, 768) identify it as Catherine Blake's signature.

lg.l: Blake(*Blake Records*, page 768) and Keynes (*Letters*, page 131) read “Blake” but the word is obscured in the manuscript.

lg.l: Ten Poundsonfurther account—Bentley (*Blake Records*, page 768) and Keynes (*Letters*, page 135) read “on” but the word is illegible due to the inkblot and the overlapping letter 'R" from the previous line.

desc.objtitle:
12 August 1818 Receipt, John Linnell, 12 August 1818,
Object 30 (Bentley Receipt 33)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 4 x 17 cm.

lg.l: Recievd Received. 12 Aug st August 1818 of Mr LinnellBentley (*Blake Records*, page 773) reads “August” for “Aug st.” Keynes (*Letters*, page 144) reads “Augst.”

desc.objtitle:
19 September 1818 Receipt, John Linnell, 19 September 1818,
Object 31 (Bentley Receipt 35)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 8.5 x 14 cm.

objnote.p: on the top left the number "28" is partially visible. The number is typed and has been obscured by tearing.

lg.l: For Laying in the Engraving of Mr UptonsBentley (*Blake Records*, page 774) and Keynes (*Letters*, page 145) read “Engraving” but the “in” of “Engraving” is unclear in the manuscript.

desc.objtitle:
9 November 1818 Receipt, John Linnell, 9 November 1818,
Object 32 (Bentley Receipt 36)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 7.5 x 18.5 cm.

objnote.p: To the left of the text is an embossed revenue stamp depicting a coronet and sprigs of long, narrow leaves on its left and right. The word “RECEIPT” appears at the top and the words “THREE/PENCE” at the bottom.

lg.l: Recievd Received 9 Novr November 18 18 of Mr LinnellBentley (*Blake Records*, page 774) and Keynes (*Letters*, page 145) read "1818". The first "8" in the date appears to be written over the number "7".
The Sum of Five Pounds on Account

desc.objtitle:
31 December 1818 Receipt, John Linnell, 31 December 1818,
Object 33 (Bentley Receipt 37)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 6.5 x 16.5 cm.

objnote.p: To the left of the text is an embossed revenue stamp depicting a shield bearing the union flag and surrounded by the motto “DIEU ET MON DROIT”. Above the shield is a coronet and on the left and right sides are sprigs of long, narrow leaves. Below the shield is the phrase “TWO PENCE / FOR RECEIPTS”.

lg.l: Recieved Received 31Decembr December 1818 of Mr LinnellBentley (*Blake Records*, page 774) and Keynes (*Letters*, page 145) read "Recieved".
the Sum of Three Pounds Fifteen Shillings
the Balance of Account of Mr Uptons Plate

desc.objtitle:
27 August 1819 Receipt, John Linnell, 27 August 1819,
Object 34 (Bentley Receipt 38)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 11 x 18.5 cm.

lg.l: Recievd Received One Pound Nineteen & Sixpence of—
Mr Linnell for Songs of Innocence & Experience

desc.objtitle:
30 December 1819 Receipt, John Linnell, 30 December 1819,
Object 35 (Bentley Receipt 39)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 11 x 18.5 cm.
physdesc.objnote: On the left side of the object, there are slanted words written in pencil in Linnell's hand. According to Bentley(*Blake Records*, 774) "Sideways in the corner of the sheet is written Linnell's note to himself:"2£. to Father Paid by Mr Varley lent 1/6"".

lg.l:
Recievd Received 30 Decembr
December 1819 of MrLinnell the sum Bentley (*Blake Records*, page 774) and Keynes (*Letters*, page 146) read the last word of this line as "sum".
of Fourteen Shillings for Jerusalem Chap Chapter 2

desc.objtitle:
30 April 1821 Receipt, John Linnell, 30 April 1821,
Object 36 (Bentley Receipt 40)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 7.5 x 18.5 cm.

objnote.p: To the left of the text is an embossed revenue stamp depicting a shield bearing the union flag and surrounded by the motto “DIEU ET MON DROIT”. Above the shield is a coronet and on the left and right sides are sprigs of long, narrow leaves. Below the shield is the phrase “TWO PENCE / FOR RECEIPTS”.

lg.l: Recievd Received April 30:1821 of Mr Linnell
the Sum of Two Guineas for Heaven & Hell

Willm
William Blake Bentley (*Blake Records*, page 774) and Keynes (*Letters*, page 146) read the last number of this price as "0".

lg.l: Recievd Received 1 March 1822 of Mr Linnell

desc.objtitle:
March 1823 Accounts Between Blake and John Linnell, March 1823 to November 1825, page 1,
Object 38 (Bentley Receipt 42.1)

physdesc.objsize: On a full sheet of paper 17.5 x 11.5 cm.

objnote.p: The full receipt, of which this is one page, is written on both sides of three loose sheets, some of which have page numbers in the top left corner. This page is numbered "2". Keynes (Letters, 151) notes that this page is the recto of second sheet.
The receipt is written in Linnell's hand with Blake's initials against each sum.
A significant part of the object is written in pencil and overwritten in pen.

desc.objtitle:
March 1823 to July 1824 Accounts Between Blake and John Linnell, March 1823 to November 1825, page 2,
Object 39 (Bentley Receipt 42.2)

physdesc.objsize: On a full sheet of paper 17.5 x 11.5 cm.

objnote.p: The full receipt, of which this is one page, is written on both sides of three loose sheets, some of which have page numbers in the top left corner. This page is not numbered. Keynes (Letters, 151) notes that this page is the verso of the second sheet.
The receipt is written in Linnell's hand with Blake's initials against each sum.
A significant part of the object is written in pencil and overwritten in pen.

lg.l: Cash Paid to Mr Blake on £ _ s .
1824 Mr Leigh's Sub.s. _____WB 2_0Keynes (Letters, p. 151) reads “Sub.s.” as “Sub.”

July 6 .Cash by Dr Thornton’s order.Mr PoWB 5. 5.Unclear pencil marks under "Mr. Thornton" and the words "Mr. Po" written in pencil are visible at the end of the line. Bentley (*Blake Records*, 806) reads "pd by MrPost".

desc.objtitle:
August 1824 to November 1825 Accounts Between Blake and John Linnell, March 1823 to November 1825, page 3,
Object 40 (Bentley Receipt 42.3)

physdesc.objsize: On a full sheet of paper 17.5 x 11.5 cm.

objnote.p: The full receipt, of which this is one page, is written on both sides of three loose sheets, some of which have page numbers in the top left corner. This page is numbered "1". Keynes (Letters, 152) notes that this page is the recto of first sheet.
The receipt is written in Linnell's hand with Blake's initials against each sum.

lg.l: The Portrait of Mr. LowryKeynes (Letters, p. 151) identifies this figure as Wilson Lowry, FRS (1762-1824), engraver and inventor WB 5–

desc.objtitle:
January to November 1825 Accounts between Blake and John Linnell, March 1823 to November 1825, page 4,
Object 41 (Bentley Receipt 42.4)

physdesc.objsize: On a full sheet of paper 17.5 x 11.5 cm.

objnote.p: The full receipt, of which this is one page, is written on both sides of three loose sheets, some of which have page numbers in the top left corner. This page is numbered "3". Keynes (Letters, 152) notes that this page is the recto of third sheet.
The receipt is written in Linnell's hand with Blake's initials against each sum.
A significant part of the object is written in pencil and overwritten in pen.
In the bottom right of the page, there are some indistinct figures and letters in pencil. Bentley (*Blake Records*, 807) and Keynes (*Letters*, 152) make no note of them.

lg.l: for one Copy - the extra 5 gs._______

not reckond
reckond reckoned against Mr Blake.
for the copy presented to him for
the library of the Royal Academy.

desc.objtitle:
14 July 1826 Receipt, John Linnell, 14 July 1826,
Object 42 (Bentley Receipt 43)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 7.5 x 18.5 cm.

objnote.p: To the left of the text is an embossed revenue stamp depicting a coronet and sprigs of long, narrow leaves on its left and right. The word “RECEIPT” appears at the top and the words “TWO SHILLING/SIX PENCE” at the centre.

The second signature, signed by the witness to this statement, is not in Blake's hand. Keynes (Letters, 161) and Bentley (Blake Records,776) identify this signature and witness as Edward John Chance, Linnell's nephew.

lg.l: Recievd Received of MrJohn Linnell . the Sum of One
Hundred & Fifty Pounds for the Copy-right & Plates
(Twenty-two in number) of the Book of Job. Publishd Published
March 1825by Me.William Blake Author of the Work

desc.objtitle:
29 July 1826 Receipt, John Linnell, 29 July 1826,
Object 43 (Bentley Receipt 44)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 7.5 x 18.5 cm.

objnote.p: To the left of the text is an embossed revenue stamp depicting a coronet and sprigs of long, narrow leaves on its left and right. The word “RECEIPT” appears at the top and the words “THREE/PENCE” at the bottom.

lg.l: Recievd Received 29 July 1826 of Mrs Aders by the hands ofKeynes (Letters, 163) and Bentley (Blake Records,776) read "Recieved"

Mr Linnell the Sum of Five Pounds Five ShillingsThere is an inkblot over the "e" of Linnell that may be read as the tittle of an "i" if "Linnell" is spelt "Linnill". Keynes (Letters, 163) and Bentley (Blake Records, 776) read "Linnell". The pound amount specified in the receipt is ambiguous. Keynes (*Letters*, 163) reads "Five" as "Two". Bentley (*Blake Records*, 776) reads "Five".

desc.objtitle:
18 May 1829 Receipt, John Linnell, 18 May 1829,
Object 44 (Bentley Receipt 45)

physdesc.objsize: On a slip of paper 8.5 x 18 cm.

objnote.p: The signature on the receipt is not in Blake's hand. Bentley (*Blake Records*, 778) and Keynes (*Letters*, 172) identify it as Frederick Tatham's signature.

lg.l: Sixpence for Homers IliadKeynes (*Letters*, 172) reads "sixpence" for "Sixpence".

&
Oddisy Odyssey –Bentley (*Blake Records*, 778) and Keynes (*Letters*, 172) read "Oddisy" but the word is obscured in the manuscript.
